item.description: La cour criminelle du Vaucluse a condamné jeudi les 51 accusés de l'affaire des viols de Mazan à des peines de 5 à 15 ans de prison pour viols aggravés, et Dominique Pelicot à 20 ans de réclusion criminelle. Des peines moins sévères que les réquisitions, ce qui soulage les avocats de la défense et révolte les collectifs féministes présents à l'extérieur du tribunal. Réactions.

item.title: Séquestration de Paul Pogba : la justice condamne son frère Mathias à un an de prison ferme
item.description: Jugé pour avoir séquestré et tenté d'extorquer avec plusieurs complices de l'argent à son frère, l'international français Paul Pogba, Mathias Pogba a été condamné jeudi à trois ans de prison, dont deux avec sursis.

item.title: François Bayrou à Matignon : seuls 36% des Français satisfaits, selon un sondage
item.description: Ce taux est nettement inférieur à celui qu’ont connu ses trois prédécesseurs lors de leur entrée en fonction à Matignon, révèle ce sondage Ifop pour Sud Radio paru jeudi 19 décembre.

item.title: François Bayrou voit s’éloigner son rêve d’un gouvernement élargi
item.description: Le premier ministre invite jeudi à Matignon les chefs de l’ensemble des forces politiques, hors Insoumis et lepénistes. Il rêve de dévoiler son équipe d’ici à Noël, mais fait face aux exigences des LR et aux réticences des socialistes.

item.title: EN DIRECT - Nouveau gouvernement : François Bayrou veut réunir «ceux qui ont échoué», cingle Jean-Philippe Tanguy
item.description: Le député du RN a raillé la réunion prévue en début d’après-midi à Matignon avec Yaël Braun-Pivet et Gérard Larcher, ainsi que «les présidents de partis et de groupes qui ont eu la responsabilité des affaires du pays à une période ou à une autre de la Ve République».

item.title: «Prendre en compte les intérêts des vivants non humains» : à Lyon, d’étranges formations au «dialogue inter-espèces» financées par la ville
item.description: La majorité écologiste lyonnaise est critiquée pour avoir dépensé 3000 euros dans un jeu de rôle destiné à ses agents. Formation dispensée par une association comportant «des membres humain.e.s et non humain.e.s» tels qu’un «bouleau pleureur» ou un «coquelicot».

item.title: Procès des viols de Mazan : «Mon client est hébété», réagit l’avocate de Dominique Pelicot qui n’exclut pas de faire appel
item.description: Béatrice Zavarro, celle qui était souvent présentée comme «l’avocate du diable», s’est exprimée dès l’annonce de la condamnation de son client et de ses 50 coaccusés.

item.title: Affaire des viols de Mazan : Dominique Pelicot écope de la peine maximale, 20 ans de réclusion criminelle
item.description: Le principal accusé des viols de Mazan a été déclaré coupable ce jeudi de «viols aggravés» sur son ex-femme.

item.title: Un octogénaire cambriolé dans le 16e arrondissement de Paris, le préjudice estimé à 15 millions d’euros
item.description: Le ou les vols, commis sans effraction en l’absence du propriétaire, auraient débuté en février 2024 dans cet appartement situé dans le 16e arrondissement de la capitale. Seule la femme de ménage possède un jeu de clés.

item.title: Toulouse : «Quand un chauffeur de bus est convoqué par sa direction pour avoir eu le courage de faire son devoir»
item.description: FIGAROVOX/TRIBUNE - Le 6 décembre à Toulouse, une violente altercation, devenue virale sur les réseaux sociaux, a éclaté entre un chauffeur de bus et deux mineurs, qui refusaient de payer leur titre de transport. La professeur Ophélie Roque y voit le symbole d’une inversion complète des valeurs.

item.title: Appréciation de l’âge des «mineurs isolés» à la frontière franco-italienne : la justice rejette la suspension du dispositif
item.description: Un protocole expérimenté dans les Alpes-Maritimes pour apprécier l’âge des présumés mineurs isolés, avant leur éventuelle prise en charge, était jugé illégal par une dizaine d’associations d’aide aux migrants, mais aussi par les syndicats de la magistrature et des avocats.

item.title: Travail à temps partiel : un rapport propose des pistes pour assouplir la réglementation
item.description: L’Inspection générale des affaires sociales (Igas) formule 20 recommandations afin de garantir qu’un recours accru au temps partiel «se traduise par un meilleur équilibre entre vie privée et vie professionnelle, tout en réduisant la précarité et les contraintes sur les salariés».

item.title: En difficulté, le chantier naval connu pour avoir construit le Titanic bientôt racheté par un groupe public espagnol
item.description: L’acquisition permettra de préserver plus de 1000 emplois, mais aussi de garantir l’exécution d’un contrat portant sur trois navires de soutien pour la marine britannique, assure le repreneur.

item.title: «Quelle dignité. Merci, Gisèle Pelicot» : Même les dirigeants politiques étrangers saluent le verdict du procès de Mazan
item.description: Après l’annonce des condamnations des 51 accusés au procès des viols de Mazan, plusieurs élus de France et d’ailleurs ont témoigné leur soutien à Gisèle Pelicot.

item.title: Procès des viols de Mazan : «C’est pour mes petits-enfants que j’ai mené ce combat», affirme Gisèle Pelicot après le verdict
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot s’est exprimée devant les caméras, quelques heures après le verdict du tribunal, qui a condamné son ex-époux à vingt ans de réclusion.

item.title: EN DIRECT - Procès des viols de Mazan : «Merci Gisèle !», scande la foule en l’applaudissant à la sortie du tribunal
item.description: Des forces de l’ordre ont entouré Gisèle Pelicot, frayant un chemin au milieu des centaines de personnes venues l’acclamer.

item.title: Procès des viols de Mazan : tous les co-accusés reconnus coupables, mais condamnés à des peines plus faibles que les réquisitions
item.description: INFOGRAPHIE - Les cinquante hommes ont tous été reconnus coupables de viol ou de tentative de viol. Dominique Pelicot, le principal accusé a, quant à lui, écopé de la peine maximale, soit 20 ans de prison.

item.title: Impôts, taxes et contrôles : ce que cache le mystérieux numéro fiscal de votre bien immobilier
item.description: DÉCRYPTAGE - Le numéro fiscal associé à tous les logements prend de plus en plus de poids. Selon les experts interrogés par Le Figaro, cet identifiant est encore très loin d’avoir livré tous ses secrets.

item.title: Affaire Paul Pogba : les maîtres chanteurs du footballeur condamnés à de lourdes peines, son frère Mathias à 1 an ferme
item.description: Les amis du pilier des Bleus ont été reconnus coupables de l’avoir séquestré, puis fait chanter en 2022, pour obtenir 13 millions d’euros. Quelques mois plus tôt, le footballeur avait décidé de prendre ses distances avec cette bande de proches d’enfance qui vivait à ses crochets.

item.title: Le gouvernement décrète le blocage des prix des produits de grande consommation à Mayotte
item.description: L’île est en état de «calamité naturelle exceptionnelle» après le passage du cyclone Chido.

item.title: Cyclone à Mayotte : le «deuil national» très politique décrété par le président des Comores
item.description: DÉCRYPTAGE - Azali Assoumani, à la tête de l’Union des Comores, ne manque pas une occasion de rappeler les revendications territoriales de l’archipel sur le territoire français.

item.title: EN DIRECT - Cyclone Chido à Mayotte : Macron veut «renforcer la lutte contre l’immigration clandestine»
item.description: Le président de la République a annoncé vouloir «rebâtir» Mayotte avec de nouveaux «critères» et «renforcer la lutte contre l’immigration clandestine». «Je ne peux pas laisser dire» que «l’État aurait ici démissionné», a-t-il ajouté.

item.title: 80 ans : les secrets du « Monde » pour décrypter l’actualité en vidéo
item.description: Les journalistes du service vidéo du « Monde » vous révèlent leurs principales techniques et astuces pour donner au grand public des clés permettant de comprendre l’actualité.

item.title: Les complémentaires santé augmenteront en moyenne leurs tarifs de 6 % en 2025
item.description: Les contrats individuels « augmenteront en moyenne de 5,3 % », tandis que les contrats collectifs « augmenteront de 7,3 % en moyenne », affirme la Mutualité française sur la base d’une enquête annuelle.

item.title: 80 ans du journal | « Allô “Le Monde” ? C’est encore Pierre Vidal-Naquet… »
item.description: Pendant un demi-siècle, l’historien Pierre Vidal-Naquet et « Le Monde » ont noué un compagnonnage très particulier. Lettres, coups de fil, articles et pétitions, cette grande conscience intellectuelle a joué dans les colonnes du quotidien le rôle de fact-checker et de lanceur d’alerte. Jusqu’à l’erreur.

item.title: Au Soudan, un système de santé à l’agonie et des médecins pris pour cible
item.description: Dans les zones de conflit, selon le syndicat des médecins soudanais, jusqu’à 90 % des établissements médicaux ont été contraints de fermer, privant de soins des millions de personnes.

item.title: Elections législatives au Tchad : l’opposition appelle au boycott, le parti au pouvoir déroule sa campagne
item.description: Les partis d’opposition estiment que « présenter des candidats à ces élections perdues d’avance, c’est apporter une caution au pouvoir, qui cherche à être légitimé ».

item.title: A Vanuatu, le séisme a fait plusieurs morts et d’importants dégâts
item.description: Les secours poursuivent la recherche de survivants dans les décombres des bâtiments détruits par le tremblement de terre de magnitude 7,3 qui a frappé mardi Port-Vila, la capitale de cet archipel du Pacifique. Le bilan humain a été ramené à « neuf décès confirmés » par les autorités, qui avaient évoqué jusque-là « au moins quatorze morts ».

item.title: François Bayrou, à peine nommé et déjà sous le feu des critiques
item.description: De sa gestion de la dévastation à Mayotte à son soutien au cumul des mandats, le nouveau premier ministre s’est défendu lors d’un « seul-en-scène » devant l’Assemblée nationale, où les oppositions l’exhortent à lever le « flou » sur son projet.

item.title: Emmanuel Macron se rendra en fin de semaine à Djibouti et en Ethiopie
item.description: Le chef de l’Etat partagera un repas de Noël avec les militaires français déployés à Djibouti, avant une visite dans la capitale éthiopienne pour l’inauguration du Palais national.

item.title: Le Belge Rik Van Looy, monarque absolu des courses cyclistes, est mort
item.description: Sprinteur exceptionnel, ce champion méticuleux affichait un palmarès unique dans le cyclisme avec pas moins de 482 succès, dont deux championnats du monde en 1960 et 1961. Il s’est éteint mercredi à l’âge de 90 ans.

item.title: Donald Trump cherche la sortie de guerre, en Ukraine et au Proche-Orient
item.description: La diversité des personnalités choisies par le président américain élu pour mettre en œuvre sa politique étrangère après son investiture, le 20 janvier, et ses déclarations récentes maintiennent l’incertitude sur ses futurs choix.

item.title: Netflix condamné à une amende de 4,75 millions d’euros par l’autorité de protection des données néerlandaise
item.description: Selon l’autorité, Netflix manquait de clarté ou fournissait des informations insuffisantes à ses clients sur ce que l’entreprise faisait de leurs données personnelles dans plusieurs domaines, entre 2018 et 2020.

item.title: Le réacteur EPR de Flamanville sera raccordé au réseau le 20 décembre, selon EDF
item.description: Le démarrage du réacteur nucléaire de nouvelle génération accuse douze ans de retard sur le calendrier initial, en raison de nombreux déboires techniques qui ont fait exploser la facture.

item.title: Certaines musiques de la cérémonie d’ouverture des Jeux olympiques de Paris 2024 réunies dans un album
item.description: Dix-huit titres composés par Victor Le Masne sont disponibles depuis ce mercredi. Parmi eux « Parade », le thème officiel des Jeux, ou « SynchroniCity », en hommage aux constructeurs de Notre-Dame de Paris. Certains morceaux manquent toutefois à l’appel.

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy définitivement condamné à trois ans de prison dont un an ferme sous bracelet électronique dans l’affaire des écoutes
item.description: La décision dans ce dossier, aussi appelé Bismuth, intervient à quelques jours de l’ouverture d’un nouveau procès pour l’ex-chef de l’Etat, celui des soupçons de financement libyen de sa campagne présidentielle 2007, qui doit s’ouvrir le 6 janvier 2025.

item.title: Au Ghana, la Cour suprême donne son accord à un projet de loi anti-LGBT+
item.description: Adopté en février par le Parlement, le texte prévoit jusqu’à trois ans de prison pour une personne ayant eu des relations homosexuelles et entre trois et cinq ans pour « la promotion, le parrainage ou le soutien intentionnel d’activités LGBT+ ».

item.title: Tchat | Le directeur du « Monde », Jérôme Fenoglio, répond à vos questions à l’occasion des 80 ans de notre rédaction
item.description: La rédaction organise cinq échanges entre ses lecteurs et ses journalistes, mercredi, à l’occasion de la date anniversaire du premier numéro du « Monde », publié le 18 décembre 1944.

item.title: Comité international olympique : David Lappartient, un outsider français pour la présidence
item.description: Le patron du CNOSF a connu une ascension éclair au sein du CIO. Face à lui, six autres candidats, dont certains très expérimentés, prétendent à la succession de l’Allemand Thomas Bach, lors de l’élection qui se tiendra du 18 au 21 mars 2025.

item.title: Les nouveaux vitraux de Notre-Dame de Paris confiés à l’artiste peintre Claire Tabouret
item.description: Ces vitraux contemporains, souhaités par Emmanuel Macron et l’archevêque de Paris, Laurent Ulrich, doivent remplacer fin 2026 six des sept baies du bas-côté sud de Notre-Dame de l’architecte du XIXᵉ siècle Eugène Viollet-le-Duc.

item.title: La justice suspend l’autorisation de quatre projets de mégabassines, dont celle de Sainte-Soline
item.description: La cour administrative d’appel de Bordeaux a jugé que ces réserves menaçaient la survie d’une espèce protégée, l’outarde canepetière. « Faute de prévoir une dérogation » pour ces espèces, les autorisations délivrées pour la construction de ces bassines sont suspendues.

item.title: « Du côté de chez Marilyn », d’Olivier Steiner et Isabelle Adjani : naguère les étoiles
item.description: L’écrivain fait valser les désirs dans un tourbillon vital polyphonique où percent sa voix et aussi celles de la star suprême et d’Isabelle Adjani. Par Pierre Michon.

item.title: Facebook et Instagram ont limité la portée des médias palestiniens, selon une enquête de la BBC
item.description: La BBC révèle que Meta a entravé la visibilité des médias et des internautes palestiniens. Des durcissements assumés par l’entreprise, qui évoque « des mesures temporaires » prises au lendemain du 7-Octobre.

item.title: Des milliers d’influenceurs, dont des Français, approchés par des personnes proches du Kremlin pour diffuser de la propagande prorusse
item.description: Selon une source au sein des services de renseignement français, plus de 2 000 producteurs de contenus européens ont été contactés. Une vingtaine d’entre eux, dont neuf Français, auraient accepté le marché.

item.title: Violences sur mineurs en familles d’accueil : des peines allant jusqu’à six ans de prison ferme pour les prévenus
item.description: Dix-huit personnes comparaissaient devant le tribunal correctionnel de Châteauroux pour des faits de violences, travail dissimulé en bande organisée, accueil de mineurs sans déclaration préalable et administration de substance nuisible ou usage de faux en écriture.

item.title: En Normandie, une femme porte plainte contre l’enseignement catholique pour discrimination en raison de son orientation sexuelle
item.description: Sur les réseaux sociaux, la plaignante avait posté des vidéos où elle faisait part de sa vie amoureuse et de sa bisexualité. La présidente de l’organisme de gestion de l’enseignement catholique lui avait annoncé que « soumise à la pression des familles » de Bayeux, elle avait dû mettre un terme a son contrat.

item.title: Au procès de l’assassinat de Samuel Paty, les avocats de Brahim Chnina et d’Abdelhakim Sefrioui ébranlent la thèse de l’accusation
item.description: Les défenseurs des deux responsables de la campagne numérique qui a été fatale au professeur ont plaidé l’acquittement, mardi 17 et mercredi 18 décembre, en faisant valoir l’absence d’« intention terroriste ».

item.title: Parcoursup 2025 : tout ce qu’il faut savoir sur l’ouverture de la plateforme
item.description: Le site d’information ouvre mercredi, mais il ne sera possible de formuler des vœux qu’à partir du 15 janvier 2025. Plusieurs fonctionnalités ont été ajoutées pour cette huitième édition, comme un simulateur permettant d’estimer les résultats de réponses des formations en fonction des profils des candidats.

item.title: JO d’hiver 2030 : Michel Barnier pressenti pour jouer un rôle dans le Comité d’organisation
item.description: L’ancien premier ministre pourrait accompagner le lancement du futur Cojop des Jeux olympiques et paralympiques d’hiver 2030, qui auront lieu dans les Alpes françaises. Une manière de rassurer à la fois le Comité international olympique et les deux régions hôtes.

item.title: Un premier cas grave de grippe aviaire détecté chez l’homme aux Etats-Unis
item.description: Le malade, qui est actuellement hospitalisé, a été en contact avec des oiseaux malades et morts, ont affirmé les autorités sanitaires, ajoutant que 61 cas de grippe aviaire chez l’homme ont été détectés aux Etats-Unis depuis avril. La France a, quant à elle, retrouvé son statut « indemne » de la grippe qui avait été relevé à « élevé » en novembre.

item.title: Le Conseil d’Etat annule l’arrêté créant une plateforme de « taxis volants » à Paris
item.description: La haute juridiction administrative, saisie en référé, avait donné le 24 juillet un accord provisoire à ce « vertiport » installé au niveau da le gare d’Austerlitz, dans l’est de la capitale.

item.title: Le « Bondy Blog » appelle à la générosité des donateurs
item.description: A l’aube de fêter son vingtième anniversaire, le média en ligne fait un appel aux dons afin de contrebalancer la baisse drastique de ses subventions publiques.

item.title: Poursuivi pour complicité de harcèlement moral, Bruno Lasserre, l’ancien patron de l’Autorité de la concurrence, a été relaxé
item.description: Il était poursuivi pour « complicité de harcèlement moral » après le suicide d’un salarié en mars 2014 alors qu’il était à la tête de l’organisation. Alain Mouzon avait dénoncé l’épuisement professionnel dont il avait été victime.

item.title: Des distributeurs de cryptomonnaies illégaux, installés dans des épiceries ou des taxiphones, saisis par la justice
item.description: Une douzaine d’appareils ont été saisis par les autorités françaises. Nichés dans des boutiques comme des restaurants de kebabs ou des revendeurs de téléphones, ils sont soupçonnés de servir à des opérations de blanchiment.

item.title: « Le président et son double » (1/4) | Emmanuel Macron, une certaine idée du pouvoir
item.description: Alors que la décision d’Emmanuel Macron de dissoudre l’Assemblée nationale a provoqué une crise politique majeure, « Le Monde » revient dans une série d’articles sur l’évolution déroutante du chef de l’Etat.

item.title: TikTok aux Etats-Unis : la Cour suprême examinera la loi menaçant le réseau social chinois d’interdiction
item.description: L’entrée en vigueur de la loi contraignant TikTok à vendre sous peine d’être interdit aux Etats-Unis, prévue le 19 janvier, n’a pas été suspendue par la Cour, mais les débats sont prévus le 10 janvier.

item.title: Une tablette gravée des dix commandements, présentée comme la plus ancienne au monde, vendue 5 millions de dollars aux enchères
item.description: Découverte en 1913 lors d’excavations pour la construction d’un chemin de fer sur l’actuel territoire d’Israël, la tablette porte l’inscription des versets de neuf des dix commandements qui apparaissent dans la Bible et la Torah. Certains experts remettent en doute son authenticité.

item.title: En Tunisie, au moins vingt migrants morts noyés dans un naufrage au large de la ville de Sfax
item.description: Les secours poursuivent les recherches après avoir pu secourir cinq migrants originaires d’Afrique subsaharienne.

item.title: Grippe aviaire : l’état d’urgence déclaré en Californie
item.description: La décision est intervenue, mercredi, alors que les autorités sanitaires fédérales venaient de confirmer le premier cas grave de transmission à l’homme du virus H5N1 dans le pays.

item.title: La Fed fait chuter Wall Street avec le ralentissement de la baisse des taux
item.description: La Bourse de New York perd 3 % en raison des inquiétudes de la Fed sur l’inflation. Le dollar a bondi de 1 % après les prévisions de la banque centrale américaine. La baisse des taux d’un quart de point était jugée acquise par les marchés.

item.title: Ligue 1 : le PSG renverse Monaco pour prendre le large en tête du classement
item.description: Les Parisiens possèdent dix points d’avance sur les Monégasques après leur victoire dans la Principauté (4-2), mercredi soir, en match avancé de la 16ᵉ journée.

item.title: Donald Trump accroît le risque d’un shutdown en exprimant son opposition à un accord budgétaire aux Etats-Unis
item.description: Le président élu américain demande aux républicains de revenir sur un texte bipartisan qui permettrait d’éviter un blocage fédéral avant l’heure fatidique de vendredi soir, minuit. Les démocrates dénoncent l’influence d’Elon Musk dans cette décision.

item.title: Pourquoi la saison de Noël commence de plus en plus tôt
item.description: Achats de sapin et de décorations en novembre, téléfilms et promotions dès octobre : l’ancienne fête ascétique de deux jours s’est muée en saison festive de plus de deux mois. Une tendance qui s’explique par des raisons à la fois commerciales et culturelles.

item.title: A Mayotte, après le passage du cyclone Chido, le gouvernement active l’état de « calamité naturelle exceptionnelle » pour faciliter la gestion de la crise
item.description: Emmanuel Macron est attendu, jeudi matin, dans l’archipel où il se rendra notamment « dans un quartier détruit ». Les secours continuent d’affluer sur le territoire afin d’assurer les besoins vitaux en eau et en nourriture de la population.

item.title: Marine Le Pen et Jean-Luc Mélenchon anticipent leur duel présidentiel
item.description: Les leaders de l’extrême droite et de la gauche radicale espèrent hâter l’élection présidentielle de 2027. Et envisagent un face-à-face qu’ils considèrent comme leur meilleure chance d’accéder à l’Elysée.

item.title: Quatre agents du renseignement français détenus au Burkina Faso depuis un an ont été libérés
item.description: Accusés d’espionnage, ils avaient été arrêtés à Ouagadougou le 1er décembre 2023. Emmanuel Macron a remercié le roi du Maroc pour « la réussite de la médiation » qui a permis leur libération.

item.title: Darty, Boulanger, Electrolux, Whirlpool… 12 fabricants et distributeurs d’électroménager condamnés à 611 millions d’euros d’amende pour entente sur les prix
item.description: L’Autorité de la concurrence leur reproche de s’être entendus pour maintenir des prix de vente élevés entre 2007 et 2014. Le montant de l’amende concernant Fnac Darty s’éleve à 109 millions d’euros.

item.title: Guinée : Mohamed Diané, ancien tout-puissant ministre de la défense, condamné à cinq ans de prison
item.description: L’homme fort du régime d’Alpha Condé a été jugé coupable de détournement de fonds publics, d’enrichissement illicite, de blanchiment de capitaux et corruption d’agents publics.

item.title: En direct, nouveau gouvernement : François Bayrou reçoit les forces politiques, hors RN et LFI, à Matignon
item.description: Le premier ministre a adressé mercredi une lettre aux chefs de groupe parlementaire et de parti (excluant La France insoumise, le Rassemblement national et l’Union des droites pour la République), ainsi qu’aux présidents des deux Chambres, les invitant à l’hôtel de Matignon jeudi après-midi afin de leur présenter ses orientations.

item.title: 2024 dans le top 5 des années les plus chaudes, malgré la pluie et l’absence de soleil
item.description: Selon le bilan de Météo-France, 2024, marquée par de nombreuses inondations, figurera parmi les dix années les plus pluvieuses et l’une des cinq plus chaudes jamais enregistrées.

item.title: En direct, guerres au Proche-Orient : le Hamas estime que les bombardements israéliens au Yémen constituent une « escalade dangereuse »
item.description: « Nous considérons cette surenchère comme une escalade dangereuse et une extension de l’agression contre le peuple palestinien, la Syrie et le monde arabe », a affirmé le mouvement islamiste dans un communiqué publié quelques heures après les frappes, dont les autorités israéliennes disent qu’elles répondaient à un tir de missile du « régime terroriste houthiste ».

item.title: En direct, cyclone Chido à Mayotte : Emmanuel Macron annonce qu’il y restera jusqu’à vendredi, un « hôpital de campagne » sera installé
item.description: Le chef de l’Etat a atterri, jeudi matin, à l’aéroport de Mayotte, à bord d’un A330 transportant également de l’eau et des médicaments. Après une reconnaissance aérienne, Emmanuel Macron s’est rendu au centre hospitalier de Mamoudzou.

item.title: Trophée Jules-Verne : François Gabart et son équipage sont repartis à l’assaut du record du tour du monde
item.description: Le trimaran « SVR-Lazartigue » a repris la mer dans la nuit de mercredi à jeudi après des réparations consécutives à une avarie survenue le 3 décembre. L’équipage vise un nouveau record du tour du monde à la voile, sans escale et sans assistance.

item.title: La Corse placée vendredi en vigilance orange pour risques de vents forts par Météo-France
item.description: De violentes rafales pouvant atteindre 120 kilomètres à l’heure et balayant les villes côtières sont attendues vendredi, selon l’agence météorologique, qui souligne le caractère inhabituel de la situation.

item.title: En direct, procès des viols de Mazan : « Tous les accusés ont été déclarés coupables, c’est la leçon essentielle de ce procès »
item.description: Nos chroniqueurs judiciaires Pascale Robert-Diard et Henri Seckel ont répondu à vos questions. Après trois mois et demi d’audience, la cour criminelle du Vaucluse a voulu marquer, jeudi, une très nette différence entre l’ex-mari de Gisèle Pelicot – condamné à vingt ans de prison – et ses 50 coaccusés – de trois ans à quinze ans de prison.

item.title: MrBeast, le youtubeur star qui assume la démesure
item.description: Le vidéaste le plus suivi au monde sur YouTube lance, sur fond de polémiques, une nouvelle émission de téléréalité sur Prime Video. Sommes exorbitantes, débauche de moyens et succès calibrés sont la marque de ses productions.

item.title: A Chamonix, le club de ski alpin a décidé « de faire sa modeste part » face au changement climatique
item.description: Le club se mobilise, depuis trois ans, pour réduire son empreinte carbone. Pour ses dirigeants, qui observent d’année en année la dégradation de leur environnement, il y a urgence d’agir à leur échelle.

item.title: Nucléaire : les leçons de l’EPR de Flamanville, sur le point d’être connecté au réseau électrique
item.description: Avec douze ans de retard, le réacteur nucléaire de nouvelle génération de la centrale située à Flamanville, dans la Manche, doit être relié au réseau vendredi 20 décembre, a annoncé EDF.

item.title: Natacha Polony quitte la direction de l’hebdomadaire « Marianne », remplacée par Frédéric Taddeï
item.description: La ligne éditoriale souverainiste portée par la directrice de la rédaction ne convenait plus au milliardaire proeuropéen Daniel Kretinsky, qui tentait de céder le magazine depuis avril. Après deux échecs de reventes, le groupe CMI France annonce finalement son intention de conserver le magazine.

item.title: Formule 1 : le départ de Sergio Pérez de Red Bull, dernier exemple du chamboulement en cours dans le paddock
item.description: Le Mexicain a annoncé, mercredi, qu’il quittait l’écurie autrichienne, remplacé par le Néo-Zélandais Liam Lawson. Pour la saison 2025, la moitié des monoplaces auront un nouveau pilote.

item.title: En direct, guerre en Ukraine : disant avoir été « contraint » de lancer l’offensive, Vladimir Poutine affirme qu’il aurait dû le faire « plus tôt »
item.description: Le président russe se prête jeudi à sa séance annuelle de questions-réponses, un show télévisé largement mis en scène mais aussi une rare opportunité pour l’interroger sur des sujets qui fâchent.

item.title: En Géorgie, un député tué et un autre blessé dans une fusillade au Parlement de la région séparatiste d’Abkhazie
item.description: Le service de presse de l’actuel dirigeant séparatiste abkhaze, Badra Gounba, n’a pas donné plus de précisions sur le déroulé, ni sur les auteurs du drame.

item.title: American-backed forces work to keep ISIS at bay in Syria
item.description: The U.S. has been conducting airstrikes in Syria since the fall of the Assad regime, in part, it says, to prevent a resurgence of ISIS. Holly Williams got an on-the-ground look at how American-backed forces in Syria are also working to disrupt the group.

item.title: Man stopped at border crossing with dead woman in passenger seat
item.description: The officers became suspicious after noticing the female passenger "was not conscious and was not communicating."

item.title: Dad and stepmom jailed for "campaign of abuse" that killed U.K. girl
item.description: The stepmother and father of Sara Sharif have been sentenced to life in prison for horrific abuse that ended up killing the 10-year-old British girl.

item.title: Quake rocks Pacific island Vanuatu, reportedly killing at least 6 people
item.description: A deadly earthquake has struck the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, damaging buildings in the capital, including one housing the U.S. embassy.

item.title: DNA evidence leads to suspect 28 years after deadly stabbing
item.description: Police in the Canadian capital of Ottawa say they have arrested and charged a suspect in the deadly stabbing of Christopher Smith in 1996.

item.title: Argentinian President Javier Milei plans to attend Trump inauguration
item.description: Milei is the first world leader expected to be in Washington, D.C. for President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, though arrangements are underway for others to join.

item.title: U.S. deports notorious drug lord dubbed "Friend Killer" back to Mexico
item.description: Osiel Cárdenas Guillén created the most bloodthirsty gang of hitmen Mexico has ever known, the Zetas.

item.title: Bronze-Age Britons were cannibalized after massacre, research shows
item.description: Researchers determined that dozens of men, women and children were violently killed and cannibalized in Bronze Age-era England.

item.title: 12/16: CBS Evening News
item.description: Student and teacher killed in Madison, Wisconsin, school shooting; Supreme Court Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson makes Broadway history

item.title: Ukraine says it assassinated top Russian general
item.description: Ukraine is claiming responsibility for the assassination of a top Russian general in Moscow. Lt. General Igor Kirillov, who oversaw Russia's chemical weapons unit, was killed when a bomb hidden in a scooter went off as he left a Moscow apartment building. Haley Ott reports.

item.title: Ukraine claims blast that killed head of Russia's chemical weapons unit
item.description: The head of Russia's chemical and biological forces, Lt. General Igor Kirillov, was killed in a Moscow bomb blast claimed by Ukraine.

item.title: 12/17: CBS Evening News
item.description: UnitedHealthcare CEO murder suspect indicted on new charges; 25 movies added to Library of Congress film registry

item.title: Russia says suspect detained in killing of top general in Moscow blast
item.description: Russian officials say a man has been detained over the killing of Lt. General Igor Kirillov, who led Russia's chemical and biological weapons unit.

item.title: Congo says mysterious disease killing dozens of kids finally identified
item.description: "The mystery has finally been solved," Congo's health ministry says, after an unidentified disease outbreak started killing mainly women and children in a remote region.

item.title: U.S. asked to extradite accused mastermind of journalist's murder
item.description: Damaso Lopez Serrano — who is known as "Mini Lic" — is accused of ordering the 2017 killing of award-winning journalist Javier Valdez.

item.title: Explosion kills 2 soldiers in suspected booby trap by drug cartel
item.description: Before the blast, the soldiers had discovered the dismembered bodies of three people, officials said.

item.title: Boeing Starliner astronauts' return to Earth delayed again
item.description: The return of two Boeing Starliner astronauts at the International Space Station is being delayed again, NASA says. Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams traveled to the space station aboard Boeing's Starliner in June for what was supposed to be an eight to 10 day trip. They are set to return to Earth on a SpaceX capsule, but that capsule needs more work, pushing back the astronauts' return date.

item.title: Ancient inscription may rewrite Christianity's history, researchers say
item.description: The "Frankfurt Silver Inscription" shows the earliest evidence of Christianity north of the Alps.

item.title: New CBS News documentary explores efforts to bridge divides between Muslims and Jews
item.description: "Finding Common Ground: Muslims and Jews Bridging the Gap" showcases the work of NewGround, a Los Angeles-based nonprofit fostering dialogue on divisive issues. The documentary comes amid heightened tensions following the Oct. 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel and subsequent conflict. Aziza Hasan, the nonprofit's executive director, and Andrea Hodos, its associate director, join "CBS Mornings."

item.title: Undersea internet cables face new threats
item.description: With undersea cables linking the world's continents, recent incidents involving foreign vessels raise questions about their security. Chris Krebs, former Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency director, weighs in on the growing threats.

item.title: China continuing nuclear buildup, strengthening ties to Russia, Pentagon says
item.description: A new Pentagon report says China is continuing to expand its nuclear force and has strengthened its ties with Russia over the past year.

item.title: U.K. court clears seizure of millions in unpaid taxes from Andrew Tate
item.description: A British court has cleared police to seize $3.3 million from misogynist social media influencer Andrew Tate and his brother to cover unpaid taxes.

item.title: Prominent pro-Putin ballet star Sergei Polunin says he's leaving Russia
item.description: Ukrainian-born ballet phenom Sergei Polunin was rewarded for backing Putin's attacks on his native country, but he appears to have fallen from Moscow's graces.

item.title: New details of Captagon drug trade exposed with Assad regime's collapse
item.description: A CBS News team gained access to a site outside Damascus which holds the precursor chemicals for Captagon, one of the most popular street drugs in the Middle East and beyond.

item.title: 12/18: CBS Evening News
item.description: Last-minute government funding bill in limbo after opposition from Trump, others; Lawmakers target AI-generated “deepfake pornography”

item.title: 2 soldiers killed by landmine day after troops killed by booby trap
item.description: The incident happened one day after a blast caused by another improvised landmine killed two Mexican soldiers and wounded five others.

item.title: Mayotte cyclone survivors plead with visiting French president for help
item.description: "Mayotte is demolished," an airport security agent told President Emmanuel Macron as he arrived in the remote French territory five days after Cyclone Chido.

item.title: 2 highway crashes in Afghanistan leave dozens dead, dozens more hurt
item.description: Two highway crashes in southeastern Afghanistan killed a combined total of 50 people and injured 76, a government spokesman says.

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot's ex-husband, over 40 others convicted in rape, drugging trial
item.description: Gisèle Pelicot said she had no regrets, but hope for the future after a judge sentenced her ex-husband to 20 years in prison for drugging and raping her for years.

item.title: Google Maps shows suspected corpse, helps solve murder mystery
item.description: Officers arrested a woman who was the missing male's partner and another man who was her ex-partner, police said.

item.title: US funding plan collapses as Trump makes demands days before shutdown
item.description:
Trump rejects bipartisan plan, causing Congress to spiral as lawmakers try to wrap up for holidays amid Friday deadline

Donald Trump abruptly rejected a bipartisan plan on Wednesday to prevent a Christmastime government shutdown, instead telling House speaker Mike Johnson and Republicans to essentially renegotiate – days before a deadline when federal funding runs out.

The president-elect’s sudden entrance into the debate and new demands sent Congress spiraling as lawmakers are trying to wrap up work and head home for the holidays. It leaves Johnson scrambling to engineer a new plan before Friday’s deadline to keep government open.

Continue reading...

item.title: US environmental agency fast tracking new PFAS approvals for semiconductors
item.description:
Hastened reviews of compounds as industry ramps up could increase pollution from likely toxic chemicals

The Environmental Protection Agency is quietly fast tracking approval of new PFAS “forever chemicals” for use by the semiconductor industry at the same time the agency is publicly touting increased scrutiny of new PFAS and other chemicals.

As US semiconductor production ramps up, the hastened reviews could sharply increase pollution containing little-studied PFAS that are likely toxic, accumulative in the environment and contribute to climate change.

Continue reading...

item.title: First Thing: 51 men found guilty in Pelicot mass rape trial
item.description:
French man jailed for 20 years over abuse of ex-wife Gisèle Pelicot. Plus, Human Rights Watch accuses Israel of genocide for restricting Gaza water supply

  • Don’t already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up here

Good morning.

A panel of judges has declared all of the 51 defendants in France’s mass rape case to be guilty, after a three-month trial that sent shockwaves around the world.

Who are the men convicted of rape and assault? They include a soldier, a nurse, a butcher, a truck driver, a supermarket worker and dozens more. But the Pelicot children have said they are “disappointed by the low sentences”, Agence France-Presse reports.

What happens now? “The surge of united feminist feeling that has risen throughout France is a springboard from which we can continue our battle for equality and justice,” said Clémence Guetté, the vice-president of France’s national assembly.

Follow our live coverage here.

What levers could Trump pull to attack critics? He could use the justice department and Internal Revenue Service to target non-profits and researchers, launch politically motivated investigations and pass legislation to restrict their activities.

What have Trump’s nominees for top government roles said? Kash Patel, Trump’s nominee for FBI director, has vowed to “come after” media outlets and non-profits that he falsely claims “helped Joe Biden rig presidential elections”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Why do Black women consistently vote Democrat?
item.description:
No other demographic has maintained the level of voter loyalty for a party as Black women have – experts tell us why

For decades, Black women have been the most ardent supporters of the Democratic party. Most recently, in the 2024 election, they voted for Kamala Harris at 92%. Since 1972, Black people’s overall support for Democrats has stayed at about 90% during a presidential election, with Black women voting even more Democratic than Black men. No other demographic has maintained that level of voter loyalty for a political party.

Donald Trump’s victory over the vice-president, and success with certain voting blocs such as Latino men and white women, has drawn attention to just how differently situated Black women are when compared with other voters.

Continue reading...

item.title: Clergy abuse survivors say there’s still ‘long ways to go’ after sentencing of New Orleans priest
item.description:
One survivor says local archbishop ‘should have been sitting right there next to’ abuser Lawrence Hecker at his hearing

The clergy abuse survivor who successfully pursued a child rape charge against retired Roman Catholic priest Lawrence Hecker in New Orleans says the local archbishop “should have been sitting right there next to” the serial molester clergyman at his criminal sentencing hearing on Wednesday.

A statement issued by the survivor after the 93-year-old Hecker received a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment Wednesday alluded to how New Orleans archbishop Gregory Aymond has repeatedly expressed a desire in the media to “walk with” the victims of the worldwide Catholic church’s decades-old clergy molestation scandal.

Continue reading...

item.title: Revealed: how a US public university courted the gas industry despite climate impacts
item.description:
McNeese State University in Louisiana building a liquefied natural gas center, prompting fears of ‘corporate capture’

One of Louisiana’s top public universities has prompted concerns about “corporate capture” over its expanding relationship with the liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry, despite environmental warnings about pollution and prolonging fossil fuel use.

As the US’s LNG boom gained momentum in south-west Louisiana, McNeese State University courted the industry to help launch a new LNG Center of Excellence currently under construction, hired a director doubling as an LNG industry lobbyist, and approached federal regulators to co-locate their own research center at the university, according to emails obtained via public records requests by DeSmog and the Guardian.

Continue reading...

item.title: Minimum term increased for 13-year-olds over Wolverhampton murder
item.description:
Sentences for boys who killed Shawn Seesahai when they were 12, UK’s youngest knife murderers, raised to at least 10 years

Britain’s youngest knife murderers, who killed a 19-year-old man with a machete when they were 12, have had their sentences increased to a 10-year-minimum prison term at the court of appeal.

The two boys, now 13, were initially given life sentences with minimum terms of eight and a half years for the murder of Shawn Seesahai in Wolverhampton in November 2023.

Continue reading...

item.title: Thames Water to pay £18m penalty after breaking dividend rules
item.description:
Regulator says it will claw back £131m in ‘unjustified’ payments as it announces companies can increase bills by 36% by 2030

  • Water bills for households in England and Wales to rise by 36%

Thames Water will have to pay an £18.2m penalty after the water industry regulator confirmed the troubled utilities company had breached dividend rules.

The Guardian revealed on Wednesday that Thames would be penalised over two dividend payments, made in 2023 and 2024, and that it would allow the water company to increase bills by just over a third. The industry watchdog Ofwat confirmed the penalty and bills rise on Thursday.

Continue reading...

item.title: HS2 boss blames failure to control costs on rush to start work
item.description:
Mark Wild says ‘fundamental reset’ needed, as Department for Transport admits it has no final cost estimate

Enormous budget overruns on the HS2 high-speed railway have been blamed by its new chief executive on a “rush to start”, as the Department for Transport admitted it did not know how much it would cost.

Mark Wild, the chief executive of HS2 Ltd, told MPs a “fundamental reset” was needed but a new plan would take until mid-2026 to devise. “We have to acknowledge that HS2 in its core mission to control costs has failed,” he said. “We must break the cycle.”

Continue reading...

item.title: Inflation fears trump growth concerns among Bank of England’s MPC members
item.description:
The monetary policy committee voted six to three to hold interest rates steady despite consumers’ reticence to spend

  • Business live – latest updates

There was no doubt in the City that the Bank of England would hold interest rates at 4.75%. An increase in annual inflation last month and a sharp rise in wages in the autumn meant its monetary policy committee (MPC) was widely expected to hold fire on a third rate cut this year.

What many will find more surprising is the yawning gap between the six committee members who voted to hold rates and the three who voted for a reduction.

Continue reading...

item.title: Average water bill in England and Wales to rise by 36% over five years
item.description:
Firms accused of forcing households to pay for years of underinvestment after Ofwat agrees to increases to help fix sector

• Thames Water to pay £18m penalty after breaking dividend rules

Water bills in England and Wales will rise by 36% over the next five years, as suppliers were accused of forcing struggling households to pay for years of underinvestment to fix leaky pipes and cut pollution.

The industry regulator Ofwat said on Thursday that, from next April, it would allow companies to raise average bills by £31 a year, or £157 in total, over the next five years to £597 by 2030 to help pay for investment. That represents a 36% increase before inflation, which will be added on top.

Continue reading...

item.title: HS2 boss defends spending £100m on ‘bat shed’ that Starmer described as ‘absurd’ – UK politics live
item.description:
Mark Wild also admitted that HS2 had been rushed and ‘construction started way too early’

In her response to the statement from Karin Smyth, Caroline Johnson, the shadow health minister, suggested the extra money for hospices would not fully compensate the extra costs the sector is facing because of the national insurance increase and the rise in the living wage. She said:

On October 30 the chancellor decided to break her election promise by increasing employers’ national insurance contributions and reducing the threshold at which employer contributions are payable.

It was later confirmed that hospices would not be exempted from this increase in costs. Now the government has announced new funding for the sector, which they had the audacity to call the biggest investment in a generation.

The biggest investment in a generation for hospices has been announced by the government today, ensuring that hospices can continue to deliver the highest quality end of life care possible for their patients, families, and loved ones.

The £100m funding will help hospices this year and next to provide the best end of life care to patients and their families in a supportive and dignified physical environment.

Continue reading...

item.title: Husband and wife to be forced apart by Home Office deportation flight
item.description:
Man scheduled to depart for Pakistan on Tuesday, leaving wife in UK, but believes his life will be at risk

A husband and wife face enforced separation because the Home Office wants to put him on a deportation flight to Pakistan on Tuesday, leaving his wife in the UK.

Labour has pledged to increase deportations, and since taking office, has removed more than 10,000 people – a mix of voluntary returnees, those denied asylum and people with criminal convictions. There has not been a deportation charter flight to Pakistan since February 2020, with three subsequent deportation charter flights to Pakistan in 2020 and 2021 cancelled by the Home Office.

Continue reading...

item.title: Zakir Hussain, legendary Indian tabla musician, dies aged 73
item.description:
The classical musician, who performed with George Harrison and Van Morrison, died in a San Francisco hospital on Sunday

Zakir Hussain, one of India’s most accomplished classical musicians who defied genres and introduced tabla to global audiences, has died aged 73.

The Indian classical music icon died from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, a chronic lung disease, at a hospital in San Francisco on Sunday, his family said in a statement.

Continue reading...

item.title: Youngest world chess champion Gukesh returns to hero’s welcome in India
item.description:
Teenager receives raucous reception after defeating China’s Ding Liren in tense 14-game series

Indian chess star Gukesh Dommaraju returned to a hero’s welcome in his home city on Monday after becoming the youngest world champion aged only 18.

Hundreds of fans crowded the arrivals area of Chennai airport, cheering alongside banks of television cameras as Gukesh made his way out of the airport after victory in taking the World Chess Championship title.

Continue reading...

item.title: Netanyahu says Israel will occupy Syria buffer zone for foreseeable future
item.description:
Israeli PM on visit to Mount Hermon says troops will remain until ‘another arrangement’ for security is found

  • Middle East crisis – live updates

Benjamin Netanyahu has said Israeli troops will occupy a recently seized buffer zone in Syria for the foreseeable future, as intense efforts continued to reach a ceasefire deal in Gaza.

The Israeli prime minister made the remarks on Tuesday night while touring Mount Hermon – known to Syrians as Jabel Sheikh – as a report in Israel suggested the Israel Defense Forces had been ordered to hold positions there until the end of 2025.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‘Everything is gone’: how Israeli forces destroyed Jabaliya refugee camp
item.description:
A chronicle of Jabaliya’s destruction, using eyewitness accounts, satellite imagery and video footage

On the morning of 9 October 2023, the Trans area of the open market in Jabaliya refugee camp was bustling. Two days into the Gaza war triggered by Hamas’s surprise attack in Israel, it had yet to be hit by Israeli jets.

The camp, just north of the city of the same name, was established in 1948. Though technically still a refugee camp, in the ensuing decades it had become largely indistinguishable from the rest of northern Gaza’s urban sprawl – densely populated, vibrant and busy. As well as the large open market at its centre, there were restaurants and schools, two football teams, bakeries and clinics.

Continue reading...

item.title: Middle East crisis: Israel issues fresh Gaza evacuation order despite increasing ceasefire hopes – as it happened
item.description:
This live blog is now closed. For the latest on the Middle East, you can see our full coverage here.

Here are some of the latest images coming through from Gaza:

Palestinian medics say an Israeli airstrike has killed at least 10 people in a house in the northern town of Beit Lahiya, where army forces have operated since October.

Continue reading...

item.title: Israel accused of act of genocide over restriction of Gaza water supply
item.description:
Human Rights Watch says Israeli forces have acted deliberately to cut availability of clean water

Israel’s restriction of Gaza’s water supply to levels below minimum needs amounts to an act of genocide and extermination as a crime against humanity, a human rights report has alleged.

Human Rights Watch (HRW) investigated Israeli attacks on the water supply infrastructure in Gaza over the course of its 14-month war there.

Continue reading...

item.title: Israel launches deadly air raids against Yemen after missile attack
item.description:
Dozens of combat jets involved in strikes that left at least nine people dead in the port city of Hodeidah

  • Middle East crisis – live updates

Israeli jets have launched widespread air raids against Houthi targets in Yemen, killing at least nine people in the port city of Hodeidah.

According to Israeli media, dozens of combat jets along with fuelling and intelligence aircraft took part in the raids, which came after reports that Israel was planning to hit Yemen with force following a recent increase in Houthi attacks against Israel, including two in the past week.

Continue reading...

item.title: Middle East crisis live: MSF accuses Israel of ‘ethnic cleansing’ in Gaza
item.description:
Report from medical group documents 41 attacks on staff including airstrikes on health facilities and direct fire on humanitarian convoys

At least 45,129 Palestinians have been killed and 107,338 injured in Israel’s military offensive on Gaza since 7 October 2023, the Gaza health ministry said in a statement on Thursday.

Iraq started on Thursday to send Syrian soldiers back to their homeland, state media reported.

Continue reading...

item.title: Independent TD Verona Murphy voted in as Ireland’s first female speaker
item.description:
Her election is first action in moves to form new coalition government after no party won majority in general election

Verona Murphy has become the first female speaker of the Irish parliament as part of attempts to form a coalition government.

Murphy, an independent TD for Wexford, defeated two Fianna Fáil candidates and one from Sinn Féin to win the €255,000 (£210,000) a year position of Ceann Comhairle.

Continue reading...

item.title: Australia to reopen embassy in Ukraine as its total support for country surpasses $1.5bn
item.description:
Foreign affairs minister Penny Wong says ambassador to Ukraine to return to Kyiv in January and Russia war affects security of Indo-Pacific

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Australia’s support for Ukraine will surpass $1.5bn as it offers more aid and reveals an embassy will reopen in the war-torn country for the first time since 2022.

The ambassador to Ukraine, Paul Lehmann, and the deputy head of mission will return to Kyiv in January, the foreign affairs minister, Penny Wong, said from the nation’s capital on Thursday.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

item.title: Navantia to buy Titanic builder Harland & Wolff, saving about 1,000 jobs
item.description:
Northern Ireland secretary hails rescue deal reached with Spanish state-owned company that secures all four shipyards

  • Business live – latest updates

A Spanish state-owned shipbuilder will buy Belfast-based Harland & Wolff in a rescue deal that will secure all four of its shipyards and save about 1,000 jobs.

Navantia is to acquire H&W’s Belfast shipyard where the Titanic was built, as well as the Arnish and Methil yards in Scotland, and the Appledore site in Devon, ending months of uncertainty for its employees.

Continue reading...

item.title: Gisèle Pelicot rape trial: husband jailed for 20 years as all 51 men found guilty
item.description:
Dominique Pelicot drugged his wife and invited dozens of men to rape her in their French home over nine years

  • Pelicot rape trial verdicts – live updates

Dominique Pelicot, one of the worst sex offenders in modern French history, has been sentenced to 20 years in prison for drugging his then wife, Gisèle, and inviting dozens of men to rape her in her home in the south of France over almost a decade.

The historic trial of 51 men was held in public after Gisèle Pelicot waived her right to anonymity so that “shame could change sides”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Russia-Ukraine war live: Putin says he is ready for talks ‘any time’ with Trump
item.description:
Russian leader is making annual end-of-year address and fielding questions from reporters

Poland summoned the chargé d’affaires of Belarus (a diplomat of a lower rank acting in place of an ambassador), Alexei Ponkratiev, on Thursday to protest against what it called “aggressive actions” of the Belarusian KGB spy service towards Polish diplomats accredited in Belarus and other countries.

The Polish foreign ministry did not specify what actions it was accusing the Belarus agency of having taken, but said the continuation of such provocations would be met with a “symmetrical response from the Polish side”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Pelicot rape trial: ‘I never regretted my decision to go public,’ says Gisèle Pelicot as husband and 50 others found guilty
item.description:
‘I took on this battle’ for my children and grandchildren, says Gisèle Pelicot in first comments after all 51 men found guilty

  • Gisèle Pelicot rape trial: husband jailed for 20 years as all 51 men found guilty

Ahead of the verdicts, the men charged alongside Dominique Pelicot were given the chance to make final statements on Monday. Around half of them simply said “nothing to add”.

Around 15 of them, however, asked Gisèle Pelicot for forgiveness.

Continue reading...

item.title: Hiker found in Blue Mountains after six days – as it happened
item.description:
This blog is now closed

  • Albanese government approves four coalmine expansions as Greens condemn ‘despicable’ move
  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Almost 150 Australians were flown out of Vanuatu overnight after a powerful earthquake hit the Pacific island earlier this week.

The foreign affairs minister, Penny Wong, said the 148 Australian citizens returned home on two Royal Australian Air Force aircraft in a post on X on Thursday morning.

Continue reading...

item.title: Albanese government approves four coalmine expansions as Greens condemn ‘despicable’ move
item.description:
Tanya Plibersek says projects in NSW and Queensland produce coal for making essential steel as critics say move ‘opposite of climate action’

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates
  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

The Albanese government has approved the expansion of four coalmines that climate campaigners estimate will release more than 850m tonnes of CO2 over their lifetime – equivalent to almost double Australia’s annual emissions.

The four mines will target mostly coal to be used for steelmaking with some thermal coal for burning in power stations.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

item.title: Police ignored allegations against Queensland paedophile 13 years before his arrest, mother claims
item.description:
Investigation launched over claims Brisbane woman’s complaints about childcare worker Ashley Paul Griffith were dismissed

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

An investigation has been launched after a mother claimed her complaints about one of Australia’s worst paedophiles were dismissed more than a decade before his arrest.

Former childcare worker Ashley Paul Griffith, 46, received a life sentence in October after pleading guilty to hundreds of sex offences spanning almost 20 years.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

In Australia, children, young adults, parents and teachers can contact the Kids Helpline on 1800 55 1800, or Bravehearts on 1800 272 831, and adult survivors can contact Blue Knot Foundation on 1300 657 380. The crisis support service Lifeline is 13 11 14. In an emergency, call 000. International helplines can be found via www.befrienders.org.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‘We were lucky’: boy survives being sucked through storm drain by flood waters as Queensland deluge continues
item.description:
Rain eases in state’s southeast after teen rescued in Mareeba, while firefighters battle blazes in Victoria

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates
  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

A lucky escape by a teenager sucked into a drain has prompted a heartfelt plea to avoid flood waters as showers eased in a rain-hit region.

Sunny skies were set to greet south-east Queensland after days of heavy showers caused flooding, power outages and damaged roads.

Sign up for Guardian Australia’s breaking news email

Continue reading...

item.title: Aldi liable for ‘flagrant’ copyright breach of rival brand’s packaging, Australian federal court finds
item.description:
Supermarket giant sought to use Baby Bellies’ designs for ‘its own commercial advantage’, judge says

  • Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updates
  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Supermarket giant Aldi has been found liable for copyright infringement over packaging for children’s snack foods that used a rival brand as a “benchmark” for its design.

Aldi – which once used the slogan “like brands, only cheaper” – launched a rebrand of a range of children’s snack food products including fruit-flavoured corn puffs under the Mamia brand in August 2021.

Continue reading...

item.title: Michael Leunig, Australian cartoonist, dies aged 79
item.description:
During his final days, Leunig was surrounded by his children, loved ones, classical music and sunflowers, his studio announced on social media

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

The Australian cartoonist, Michael Leunig, has died aged 79, his studio announced on Instagram on Thursday night.

“The pen has run dry, its ink no longer flowing — yet Mr. Curly and his ducks will remain etched in our hearts, cherished and eternal,” the post read.

Continue reading...

item.title: Mother of Filipina who spent 15 years on death row in Indonesia calls for pardon
item.description:
Mother of Mary Jane Veloso urges Philippine president to act so family can be reunited for Christmas, as daughter lands in Manila

The mother of Mary Jane Veloso, the Filipino domestic helper who spent almost 15 years on death row in Indonesia, has urged President Ferdinand Marcosto grant her daughter a pardon as she arrived back in the Philippines on Wednesday, ending a long battle by her supporters to bring her home.

“We cannot explain the joy of my husband and her children,” Veloso’s mother, Celia Veloso, 65, told the Guardian late on Tuesday. “We have been praying for my child to come home for a long time, and now she will be home.” She hopes her family can be reunited for Christmas.

Continue reading...

item.title: Prince Andrew’s ‘opaque’ finances provoke calls for register of royal interests
item.description:
Claims of refused FOI requests into Duke of York’s business dealings come as controversy over alleged Chinese spy continues

Getting information from government departments about the Duke of York’s past business dealings is like playing “whack-a-mole”, it was claimed, as fallout over the alleged Chinese “spy” controversy continues, with China saying it was an attempt to “smear” it.

Calling for a register of royal interests, similar to that for MPs, and a full inquiry by the public accounts committee into royal finances, researchers trying to investigate Prince Andrew’s “opaque” finances claim their freedom of information (FoI) requests are regularly refused, making their work “impossible”.

Continue reading...

item.title: South Korean president fails to appear before corruption watchdog
item.description:
Yoon Suk Yeol was summoned for questioning over attempt to impose martial law earlier this month

South Korea’s impeached president, Yoon Suk Yeol, failed to appear before the country’s corruption watchdog on Wednesday, it said, after he was summoned for questioning over his attempt to impose martial law.

Yoon was stripped of his duties by parliament over the weekend after his short-lived 3 December martial law declaration, which plunged the country into its worst political turmoil in decades.

Continue reading...

item.title: Chinese AI chip firms blacklisted over weapons concerns gained access to UK technology
item.description:
Imagination Technologies had licences with two Chinese firms – but said it had not ‘implemented transactions’ that would enable the use of technology for military purposes

Chinese engineers developing chips for artificial intelligence that can be used in “advanced weapons systems” have gained access to cutting-edge UK technology, the Guardian can reveal.

Described by analysts as “China’s premier AI chip designers”, Moore Threads and Biren Technology are subject to US export restrictions over their development of chips that “can be used to provide artificial intelligence capabilities to further development of weapons of mass destruction, advanced weapons systems and hi-tech surveillance applications that create national security concerns”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Fiji defence minister welcomes US security deal and criticises China missile test
item.description:
Pio Tikoduadua tells the Guardian the Pacific is ‘not a space for missile testing’ after China’s launch earlier this year raised concern in the region

Fiji’s defence minister has stressed the need for stability in the Pacific and welcomed moves to strengthen security ties with the US, while adding to criticism over China’s recent missile test for posing a threat to peace in the region.

Fiji, a country of about 1 million people strategically located in the Pacific, maintains ties and receives support from Washington and Beijing amid a wider struggle for influence by the two powers in the region.

Continue reading...

item.title: Will Japan’s close ties with US survive the caprice and quirks of Donald Trump?
item.description:
Japan’s complex defence alliances built up over years as protection against China could be put at risk in a Trump-launched trade war

Arguably, no country in Asia has better reason to be in a state of anxiety over the return of Donald Trump to the White House than Japan, since the US has been the linchpin of Japanese foreign and security policy since the second world war.

Back in 2017, well before he became prime minister, Shigeru Ishiba described Trump’s method as one of “placing his counterpart in a state of anxiety and tension, creating psychological instability and then initiating a deal”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Canada’s turmoil is harbinger of diplomatic havoc in second Trump term
item.description:
Chrystia Freeland’s exit as deputy prime minister shows how ‘America First’ policies can decimate political ties

  • US politics – live updates

Justin Trudeau’s political future has been thrown into doubt by the shock resignation of his own deputy, as Canada’s prime minister faces plummeting popularity and growing fears over a second Donald Trump presidency.

The sudden exit of Chrystia Freeland – the deputy prime minister and minister of finance – unleashed a political earthquake in Ottawa, prompting politicians both outside and in Trudeau’s own party to call for him to stand down.

Continue reading...

item.title: Ice deports mother and children, including newborn twins, to Mexico
item.description:
Despite the infants being US citizens, Christina Salazar and all four of her children were put on a plane on 11 December

After his wife and children, including newborn twins, were suddenly deported to Mexico by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement, a Texas man is fighting to get his family back.

Federico Arellano Jr, a US citizen, saw his wife, Christina Salazar, and their four children be taken into custody on 11 December, just three months after Salazar had given birth to their twins in Houston.

Continue reading...

item.title: Pakistan and Bahamas join push for global pact to phase out fossil fuels
item.description:
Climate-vulnerable pair add weight to proposed treaty seeking transition from coal, oil and gas in equitable way

Pakistan and the Bahamas have joined a growing bloc of climate-vulnerable countries seeking to broker a global pact to phase out fossil fuels in an equitable way, the Guardian can reveal.

The Bahamas is the 15th nation to fully endorse the proposed fossil-fuel non-proliferation treaty, which would provide a binding global roadmap to explicitly halt expansion of coal, oil and gas in a fair way – with wealthy nations responsible for the highest emissions transitioning first and fastest.

Continue reading...

item.title: Ancient bones shed new light on debate over origins of syphilis
item.description:
Study finds 9,000-year-old remains in Americas hold genomes of bacteria family that causes disease

After the French king Charles VIII invaded Italy in 1494, an unknown and disfiguring disease erupted in the army camps and duly spread across Europe when the men returned to their homelands the following year.

The epidemic is regarded as the first historical account of syphilis, but where the disease came from has been debated by scholars ever since. One camp believes it emerged in the Americas, and was brought to Europe by Columbus in 1493. Another suspects it was lurking in Europe before the explorer set sail.

Continue reading...

item.title: Bali bomb plotters moved from Guantánamo to Malaysia after guilty plea
item.description:
Malaysians imprisoned in US prison camp agreed to testify against alleged ringleader of attacks that killed 202

Two Malaysian held in Guantánamo Bay since 2006 have been returned to Malaysia, after they pleaded guilty to charges related to the deadly 2002 Bali bombings and agreed to testify against the alleged ringleader of that and other attacks.

Mohammed Farik bin Amin and Mohammed Nazir bin Lep arrived back in Malaysia, state media reported, where they will undergo a rehabilitation process before being reintegrated into society.

Continue reading...

item.title: Search for lost brother reveals dark secret of Mexico’s ‘death flights’
item.description:
As many as 1,500 people may have been thrown out of planes over the ocean in crackdown on rebel groups, including members of Abdallan Guzmán’s family

Abdallan was the sixth to be taken.

First they came for his older brother Amafer, nabbed in broad daylight on the streets of the Mexican city of Morelia. Then they came for his other brother, Armando, grabbed on the outskirts of the capital. That same day, soldiers burst into the family home, beating his younger brothers Solón and Venustiano, as well as his father Jesús – eventually they too would be taken. Finally in October, security forces took Abdallan Guzmán himself, subjecting him to the cruelest forms of torture before tossing him in prison.

Continue reading...

item.title: Cyclone Chido: many missing in Mayotte as death toll rises in south-east Africa
item.description:
Authorities impose night-time curfew to prevent looting as dozens reported killed across Mozambique and Malawi

The search for missing people has continued on the French territory of Mayotte, after Cyclone Chido devastated the islands on Saturday before sweeping through south-eastern Africa, where the death toll is climbing in Mozambique and Malawi.

Large parts of Mayotte’s main island, Grande-Terre, are still cut off from roads, internet and phone networks, as well as electricity and water.

Continue reading...

item.title: UK government denies rift with Mauritian PM over Chagos Islands deal
item.description:
Downing Street says ‘details’ being discussed after newly elected Navinchandra Ramgoolam criticised the agreement

Downing Street has denied that a deal with Mauritius to hand over control of the Chagos Islands is in peril after the new Mauritian prime minister said the arrangement as it stood was not beneficial to his country.

The agreement, under which the UK would hand over its final African colony while keeping control of the UK-US military base on the island of Diego Garcia for at least 99 years, was reached in October with the previous Mauritian administration.

Continue reading...

item.title: ‘The work damaged me’: ex-Facebook moderators describe effect of horrific content
item.description:
Former workers at Samasource say violent, graphic and sexually explicit videos left them fearful to go outside

  • More than 140 Kenya Facebook moderators sue after diagnoses of severe PTSD
  • PTSD, depression and anxiety: why former Facebook moderators in Kenya are taking legal action

When James Irungu took on a new job for the tech outsourcing company Samasource, his manager provided scant details before his training began. But the role was highly sought after and would nearly double his pay to £250 a month. Plus it offered a path out of Kibera, the vast shantytown on the outskirts of Nairobi where he lived with his young family.

“I thought I was one of the lucky ones,” the 26-year-old, said. But then he found himself ploughing through heaps of violent and sexually explicit material, including grisly accidents, suicides, beheadings and child abuse.

Continue reading...

item.title: More than 140 Kenya Facebook moderators diagnosed with severe PTSD
item.description:
Exclusive: Lawsuit brought by former moderators against parent company Meta and outsourcer Samasource Kenya

  • PTSD, depression and anxiety: why former Facebook moderators in Kenya are taking legal action
  • ‘The work damaged me’: ex-Facebook moderators describe effect of horrific content

More than 140 Facebook content moderators have been diagnosed with severe post-traumatic stress disorder caused by exposure to graphic social media content including murders, suicides, child sexual abuse and terrorism.

The moderators worked eight- to 10-hour days at a facility in Kenya for a company contracted by the social media firm and were found to have PTSD, generalised anxiety disorder (GAD) and major depressive disorder (MDD), by Dr Ian Kanyanya, the head of mental health services at Kenyatta National hospital in Nairobi.

Continue reading...

item.title: Cyclone Chido deaths rise in south-east Africa as Mayotte toll remains unclear
item.description:
Powerful storm in drought-hit region confirmed to have killed 45 people in Mozambique and 13 in Malawi

  • Mayotte before and after: satellite images show damage

The death toll from Cyclone Chido has continued to rise, with authorities confirming that 45 people were killed in Mozambique and 13 in Malawi.

French officials said the number of deaths on the Mayotte archipelago remained unclear, having previously expressed fears that hundreds, possibly thousands, of people were killed in slums flattened by the storm. So far, 22 deaths and 1,500 injuries, 200 of them critical, have been confirmed.

Continue reading...

item.title: Militia aligned with Sudanese army accused of executing men in Khartoum
item.description:
Relatives say Al-Bara’ ibn Malik brigade killed young men in Khartoum North during advance from Omdurman

Relatives and rights groups have accused fighters from an Islamist paramilitary force aligned with the Sudanese army of executing dozens of young men on suspicion of cooperating with the Rapid Support Forces in the Khartoum area.

The alleged killings occurred in September after fighters crossed a bridge over the Nile River into the city of Khartoum North from neighbouring Omdurman after weeks of trying.

Continue reading...

item.description: Dominique Pelicot received a 20-year sentence after he admitted to drugging and raping his wife, Gisèle. Here’s how the events unfolded.
