item.description: A court sentenced Mr. Pelicot to 20 years after he admitted to drugging and raping his wife, Gisèle, for nearly a decade, and inviting strangers to join him. The case has made her a feminist hero.

item.title: Syrian regime's atrocities 'have been documented all along', war crimes investigator says
item.description: UN investigators, who have been collecting evidence of the Syrian regime's crimes for years, say the fall of Assad offers a seminal opportunity to gather first-hand evidence. FRANCE 24's Charlotte Hughes reports. Sharon Gaffney speaks to Janine Di Giovanni, executive director of The Reckoning Project. She says that the atrocities committed by the Assad regime have been documented extensively since the start of the war in 2011 and that there is plenty of evidence against the perpetrators.

item.title: Trump can negotiate to stop Iran from getting nuclear bomb: Blinken
item.description: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday that President-elect Donald Trump had a window to negotiate with Iran, saying the development of a nuclear weapon by Tehran was not inevitable.

item.title: Outgoing Blinken cautious but 'hopeful' on Gaza ceasefire
item.description: With one month left before he leaves office, outgoing US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Wednesday he was "hopeful" of brokering a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza, one day after the Palestinian militant group said a deal was "closer than ever before" in the latest talks.

item.title: PSG beat Monaco but goalkeeper injured by cleat to the face
item.description: Paris Saint-Germain goalkeeper Gianluigi Donnarumma suffered a facial injury after being hit by an opponent's cleat in the team's 4-2 Ligue 1 win over Monaco on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump tries to kill bipartisan budget deal with Musk's help
item.description: US President-elect Donald Trump delivered a likely death blow to bipartisan congressional budget negotiations on Wednesday, rejecting the measure as full of giveaways to Democrats as billionaire ally Elon Musk whipped up outrage toward the bill and cheered on Republican lawmakers who announced their opposition.

item.title: Zelensky meets with key European leaders ahead of Trump's return to White House
item.description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky held talks with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte and other European leaders on Wednesday to bolster Kyiv's war effort and discuss longer-term security guarantees. Uncertainty hangs over future US support for Ukraine's effort against Russia as President-elect Donald Trump pushes for a quick end to the war.

item.title: Verdicts awaited in Pelicot mass rape trial that shook France
item.description: The mass rape trial that has sent shockwaves through France and the world is expected to close on Thursday with the conviction of Dominique Pelicot, who has admitted sedating his ex-wife, Gisèle, and inviting scores of strangers into their bedroom to rape her over a decade.

item.title: Elon Musk meets with UK far-right leader Nigel Farage
item.description: Tech billionaire Elon Musk's meeting with UK far-right firebrand Nigel Farage on Monday is fuelling concerns over a possible donation to the Reform UK party. Musk has already put his fortune and influence at the service of Donald Trump in the US and concerns are growing that he could seek to influence London's ties with Washington.

item.title: As Trump return looms, NATO chief Rutte stresses 'urgently needed' Ukraine support
item.description: During Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's visit to Brussels, NATO leader Mark Rutte urged member states on Wednesday to ramp up their military backing of Kyiv to improve Ukraine's standing over the next month. Donald Trump, who will be sworn in as US President on January 20, has claimed he'll end Russia's war in 24 hours, raising concerns that he will force the struggling Ukraine to negotiate a deal from a position of weakness.

item.title: UN sifting through evidence of Assad's human rights transgressions
item.description: As Syrians continue to search for traces of loved ones who were disappeared under Bashar al-Assad's regime, UN workers in the country have taken advantage of Assad's ouster to gather unprecedented amounts of "game changing" evidence of the former President's extensive human rights abuses.

item.title: Israel launches deadly strikes on Yemen after intercepting Houthi missile
item.description: Israel launched air strikes targeting Houthi military targets, including ports, power plants, and oil factories in Yemen's capital Sanaa and the strategic port city of Hodeidah on Thursday, killing at least nine people after the military said it had intercepted a Houthi missile targeting central Israel.

item.title: Live: Gisèle Pelicot says she 'respects the court and its verdict' after mass rape trial
item.description: French judges on Thursday found 51 defendants guilty of the mass rape of Gisèle Pelicot during decades of abuse orchestrated by her ex-husband Dominique Pelicot. The former couple’s children said they were “disappointed with the low sentences” which saw defendants handed between three and 20 years in prison. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

item.title: Ghana gives green light to anti-LGBTQ+ bill
item.description: Ghana's supreme court has rejected two bids to overturn a bill that would roll back LGBTQ+ rights. The Human Sexual Rights and Family Values Bill could lead to jail terms for people in same-sex relationships.

item.title: 'The maximum sentence of 20 years for aggravated rape has been demanded for Dominique Pelicot'
item.description: "The maximum sentence of 20 years for aggravated rape has been demanded by public prosecutors for Dominique Pelicot, Gisèle Pelicot's former husband" said FRANCE 24 journalist Selina Sykes. As for the other 50 men who stand trial beside him, they face a range of between four to 18 years for either aggravated rape or sexual assault, reported Sykes.

item.title: Dominique Pelicot sentenced to 20 years in French mass rape trial
item.description: A French court sentenced Dominique Pelicot to 20 years in prison on Thursday for drugging and recruiting strangers to rape his now ex-wife Gisèle Pelicot. His 50 co-defendents were also convicted by the court, receiving jail terms of between three and 15 years.

item.title: 🔴Dominique Pelicot and other defendants found guilty of rape: Follow France’s mass rape trial live
item.description: No description

item.title: Macron arrives in Mayotte to assess aftermath of Cyclone Chido
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron arrived Thursday in Mayotte to survey the devastation wrought by Cyclone Chido on the Indian Ocean archipelago. French authorities said at least 31 people have died and more than 1,500 people were injured, more than 200 criticall.

item.title: Burkina Faso releases four French nationals after Morocco intervenes
item.description: Four French nationals were released after a year in detention in Burkina Faso on Thursday. Relations between France and Burkina Faso deteriorated considerably after Ibrahim Traore come to power through a coup d'etat in 2022. Paris thanked Morocco for its mediation in the case.

item.title: Guilty verdicts in France's mass rape trial 'send powerful message'
item.description: A French court on Thursday found 51 men found guilty of participating in the mass rape of Gisèle Pelicot during decades of abuse orchestrated by her ex-husband. Many of the men had denied the charges against them saying that they thought Gisèle Pelicot had consented to the encounters, despite being drugged unconscious. The guilty verdicts "send a powerful message to say none of those excuses hold water for a second", said journalist Megan Clement, editor of the feminist Impact newsletter.

item.title: Google Maps camera captures man allegedly stuffing dead body into car trunk in Spain
item.description: PRESS REVIEW – Thursday, December 19: All eyes are on the French city of Avignon where the verdicts in the Pelicot rape trial are expected. Also: President Xi Jinping visits Macau as the city celebrates 25 years since its handover to China. A Google Maps update inadvertently exposes a man stuffing a body into a car trunk, allowing Spanish investigators to solve a year-old case. Finally, ground squirrels are seen devouring voles, in the first such predatory behaviour recorded in the animals!

item.title: Canada: Expats worried as Quebec freezes immigration programmes
item.description: In Canada, Quebec's provincial government has just announced, without prior warning, a freeze on permanent immigration. Two major programmes are impacted: the Regular Skilled Worker Program (PRTQ) and the graduate component of the Quebec Experience Program (PEQ). The opposition is denouncing a "lack of planning", while immigrant rights' organisations accuse the authorities of making thousands of qualified migrants pay the price for a lack of political foresight. FRANCE 24's Francois Rihouay and Joanne Profeta report, with Fraser Jackson.

item.title: Dishes for the festive season: A taste of France's traditional holiday food
item.description: There's only around a week to go until Christmas festivities here in France. Food is of course a major part of the celebrations. Shellfish, smoked salmon and foie gras are on most menus, along with the famous Yule log for dessert. For more, we speak to Guy Krenzer, creative director and executive chef at Lenôtre. He has also twice received the distinction of Meilleur Ouvrier de France.

item.title: Unwrapping Christmas celebrations in France
item.description: Join FRANCE 24 as we take a look at how we celebrate "Noël", or Christmas, in France. French people tend to have a big family lunch on Christmas Day, but the big event is in fact on Christmas Eve. Called the "réveillon de Noël", it involves eating traditional French dishes like oysters, foie gras, chestnut-stuffed turkey and a delicious log-shaped cake. Essentially, celebrating Christmas in France is all about eating until you pop. Joyeux Noël!

item.title: US faces possible government shutdown after Trump rejects stopgap bill
item.description: US President-elect Donald Trump has upended bipartisan efforts to avert a government shutdown, after he rejected a stopgap bill and pressed Republican lawmakers to either renegotiate it or risk their political careers. The new bill would have kept federal funding running at the current level until March after the current short-term spending plan expires on Friday night. Plus, the ongoing political crisis in Georgia is taking a toll on its economy, especially tourism.
